p: The aluminum hydride or alane is a material with high hydrogen content (10 wt.%). A 10 wt.% of hydrogen is very attractive; it meets the DOE targets of 6.5 wt.% of hydrogen for mobile applications. Even more, the low dehydrogenation temperature makes the alane, in principle, compatible with polymer exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) applications. AlH 3 is typically produced by the reaction of LiAlH 4 with AlCl 3 in an organic solvent, such as THF or Et 2O [ 45]: 3LiAlH 4 + AlCl 3 + nEt 2O → 4AlH 3· nEt 2O + 3LiCl↓. (12)
